item.title: U.S. sends more weapons to Israel amid growing calls for cease-fire
item.dc:creator: Matteo Moschella and Abigail Williams and Allie Raffa and Courtney Kube and Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: The U.S. is sending a fresh round of bombs to Israel, two senior administration officials told NBC News, undermining the Biden administration’s public expressions of frustration at Israel’s conduct in the war and its own efforts at brokering a cease-fire.

media:content.media:text: Smoke rises inside the Gaza Strip
media:content.media:description: Smoke rises inside the Gaza Strip, as seen from southern Israel, on March 17.

item.title: They came for Florida’s sun and sand. They got soaring costs and a culture war.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Pettypiece
item.description: Florida has seen a population boom, but many longtime residents and recent transplants say rising costs and divisive politics have them fleeing.

media:content.media:text: Beachgoers in Cocoa Beach
media:content.media:description: Beachgoers in Cocoa Beach on July 29, 2023, when ocean temperatures reached 101 degrees around the Florida Keys.

media:content.media:text: A demonstrator holds a placard reading "Ban Hate" during a 'Walkout 2 Learn' rally
media:content.media:description: Young people in Miami demonstrate in 2023 in response to Florida's crackdown on lessons surrounding race and Black history, and against a string of anti-LGBTQ laws that are affecting students.

media:content.media:text: A window air conditioning unit during a heat wave in Miami
media:content.media:description: A window air conditioning unit during a heat wave in Miami in 2023.

media:content.media:text: A aerial view of a man wading through a flooded street.
media:content.media:description: A flooded street in Orlando, Fla., following Hurricane Ian in 2022.

media:content.media:text: A supporter of President Joe Biden faces supporters of Donald Trump outside of the courthouse in Fort Pierce, Fla., where Trump attended a hearing in his classified records case on March 14.
media:content.media:description: A supporter of President Joe Biden faces supporters of Donald Trump outside of the courthouse in Fort Pierce, Fla., where Trump attended a hearing in his classified records case on March 14.

media:content.media:text: A handgun is inventoried at store that sells guns in Delray Beach
media:content.media:description: A handgun is inventoried at store that sells guns in Delray Beach, Fla., in 2023.

media:content.media:text: A woman looks at bottle of juice.
media:content.media:description: A person shops in a grocery store on July 13, 2022, in Miami as the consumer price index soared to 9.1%, marking the fastest pace for inflation since November 1981.

media:content.media:text: A supporter of Donald Trump wears a Trump bust jewelry.
media:content.media:description: A supporter of Donald Trump at a Super Tuesday election-night watch party at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on March 5.

media:content.media:text: An aerial view of a vehicle driving along a flooded street.
media:content.media:description: A flooded street in New Port Richey, Fla., after Hurricane Idalia made landfall in 2023.

item.title: ‘It’s possible’ Speaker Johnson could lose his job over Ukraine vote: GOP congressman
item.description: Rep. Don Bacon (R-Neb.) tells Meet the Press that there are “one or two people that are not team players” in the House Republican conference, and they may choose to vote to remove Speaker Johnson over a vote to support aid to Ukraine.

media:content.media:title: ‘It’s possible’ Speaker Johnson could lose his job over Ukraine vote: GOP congressman
media:content.media:description: Rep. Don Bacon (R-Neb.) tells Meet the Press that there are “one or two people that are not team players” in the House Republican conference, and they may choose to vote to remove Speaker Johnson over a vote to support aid to Ukraine.

item.title: Conservatives shell long-standing White House Easter Egg contest
item.dc:creator: Elyse Perlmutter-Gumbiner and Alexandra Marquez
item.description: Several conservative outlets did not "yolk" around this weekend when covering the White House's annual Easter celebrations, accusing it of banning religious themes from the annual children's egg decorating contest — even though that guidance predated the Biden administration, according to the first lady's office.

media:content.media:text: Decorations for the White House Easter Egg Roll
media:content.media:description: Decorations for the White House Easter Egg Roll adorn the East Colonnade of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Sen. Raphael Warnock slams Trump for selling Bibles
item.dc:creator: Summer Concepcion
item.description: Sen. Raphael Warnock, D-Ga., on Sunday excoriated former President Donald Trump over the $60 Bibles he is selling in partnership with country music star Lee Greenwood.

media:content.media:text: US President Biden campaigns in Atlanta, Georgia
media:content.media:description: Sen. Raphael Warnock at a campaign event for President Joe Biden in Atlanta on March 9.

item.title: Crews start removing first piece of twisted steel from collapsed Baltimore bridge
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Teams of engineers worked Saturday on the intricate process of cutting and lifting the first section of twisted steel from the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge, which crumpled into the Patapsco River this week after a massive cargo ship crashed into one of its supports.

media:content.media:text: Crews work on the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 30, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Crews work on the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 30, 2024.

item.title: A hormonal condition that affects millions of women is difficult for doctors to diagnose and treat. Here’s why
item.dc:creator: Caroline Hopkins
item.description: Why PCOS symptoms are so difficult to diagnose and treat, according to researchers and doctors.

media:content.media:text: Photo illustration of female reproductive system and scattered pills
Photo illustration of female reproductive system and scattered pills
media:content.media:description: After nearly a century of disagreements over what, exactly, defines the condition, as well as a lack of research, PCOS is still poorly understood. The symptoms are so varied that any single drug would be unlikely to help all patients, doctors say.

media:content.media:text: portrait
media:content.media:description: Jeni Gutke has been navigating PCOS-related health conditions for much of her adult life.

media:content.media:text: portrait weights exercise happy smile
media:content.media:description: Tallene Hacatoryan does lifestyle coaching to help women manage their PCOS symptoms.

media:content.media:text: portrait
media:content.media:description: Candice Bolden says she wants to raise awareness that PCOS is not just a fertility issue.

item.title: 10 transgender people share the 'strength and joy' of their lives after transition
item.dc:creator: Jo Yurcaba
item.description: Transgender people overwhelmingly describe their lives after transitioning as “happier,” “authentic” and “comforting” despite a deluge of state legislation that seeks to restrict their access to health care and other aspects of life.

media:content.media:text: Illustration of two abstract faces on either side of a blooming flower
media:content.media:description: NBC News asked transgender people from across the country to share how their life satisfaction has changed after transition.

media:content.media:text: portrait
media:content.media:description: Ash Orr said gender-affirming top surgery has made him feel more at home in his body.

media:content.media:text: Criss Smith
media:content.media:description: Criss Smith worked in financial services for 30 years and now works as a substitute teacher.

media:content.media:text: Gavin Grimm
media:content.media:description: Gavin Grimm, who was the plaintiff in a landmark trans rights case, and his cat, Rascal.

media:content.media:text: Dani Stewart
media:content.media:description: Dani Stewart would like to see better representation of trans people in media.

media:content.media:text: portrait
media:content.media:description: Andrea Montañez said those around her said she smiled more after her transition.

media:content.media:text: Lizzy Graham
media:content.media:description: Lizzy Graham practiced coming out to her Uber passengers before she came out to her family in 2015.

media:content.media:text: Jordan Reid
media:content.media:description: Jordan Reid said transition helped her love her singing voice.

media:content.media:text: Tiffany Jones
media:content.media:description: Tiffany Jones cosplaying as Sailor Saturn from "Sailor Moon."

media:content.media:text: Kylie Blackmon
media:content.media:description: Kylie Blackmon said "everything clicked mentally" after she came out as trans.

media:content.media:text: Cristina Piña
media:content.media:description: Cristina Piña said being trans can be difficult, but that her "existence reminds people of choice."

item.title: Powerball jackpot at almost $1 billion after no winner in latest drawing
item.dc:creator: Mirna Alsharif and Emilie Dorn
item.description: The Powerball jackpot is now almost at $1 billion — and no, this is not an April Fools' joke.

item.title: At least 7 shot, all under the age of 17, in mass shooting near Indianapolis mall
item.dc:creator: Doha Madani
item.description: Seven children were injured in a shooting outside a mall in downtown Indianapolis on Saturday night, police said.

media:content.media:text: Police on the scene after a shooting outside Circle Centre Mall in Indianapolis
media:content.media:description: Police on the scene after a shooting outside Circle Centre Mall in Indianapolis on March 30, 2024.

item.title: Chance Perdomo, actor who starred in 'Gen V,' dies after motorcycle accident at 27
item.dc:creator: Variety
item.description: Chance Perdomo, who starred in the television series "Gen V" and "Chilling Adventures of Sabrina," has died as a result of a motorcycle accident.

media:content.media:text: "Mission: Impossible - Dead Reckoning Part One" UK Premiere – VIP Access
media:content.media:description: Chance Perdomo attends a film premiere in London on June 22.
Chance Perdomo in the Netflix show "Chilling Adventures of Sabrina."

item.title: U.S. business leaders meet with China’s president as Beijing seeks closer ties
item.description: NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports from Beijing, where a number of U.S. business leaders, including the CEOs of Blackstone, Qualcomm, Bloomberg, Chubb and FedEx, met with the Chinese president

media:content.media:title: U.S. business leaders meet with China’s president as Beijing seeks closer ties
media:content.media:description: NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports from Beijing, where a number of U.S. business leaders, including the CEOs of Blackstone, Qualcomm, Bloomberg, Chubb and FedEx, met with the Chinese president

item.title: 3 Pennsylvania men convicted in 1997 killing have convictions overturned after decades in prison
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A Pennsylvania judge has overturned the convictions of three men imprisoned for decades in the 1997 slaying of a 70-year-old woman even though their DNA never matched that found at the scene, but they will remain in prison while a prosecutor decides whether to appeal.

media:content.media:text: The Delaware County courthouse in Media, Pennsylvania
media:content.media:description: The Delaware County courthouse in Media, Pa.

item.title: Man narrowly escapes saw blade barreling towards him in Oregon
item.dc:creator: Mirna Alsharif
item.description: It wasn't his time.

media:content.media:text: A man enters Quicktrips Neighborhood Market mere seconds before a large saw blade rolls quickly in his direction
media:content.media:description: A man enters Quicktrips Neighborhood Market mere seconds before a large saw blade rolls from across the parking lot in Eugene, Ore., on Thursday.

item.title: When the solar eclipse arrives, NY prisons will be locked down
item.dc:creator: Sandra Escallon and Brian Price
item.description: Preparations for April’s solar eclipse have ramped up as the highly anticipated astronomical event nears -- those preps, it turns out, include New York’s prisons.

media:content.media:text: A view of the total solar eclipse
media:content.media:description: A view of the total solar eclipse from Madras, Ore., in 2017.

item.title: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to undergo hernia surgery
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Yarden Segev
item.description: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office says the Israeli leader will undergo surgery on Sunday for a hernia.

media:content.media:text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
media:content.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu addresses the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, in Jerusalem, on Feb. 18, 2024.

item.title: Gmail revolutionized email 20 years ago
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: SAN FRANCISCO — Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin loved pulling pranks, so much so they began rolling out outlandish ideas every April Fool’s Day not long after starting their company more than a quarter century ago.

media:content.media:text: Google co-founders Sergey Brin, left, and Larry Page
media:content.media:description: Google co-founders Sergey Brin, left, and Larry Page pose at company headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., in 2004.

item.title: An Israeli airstrike hits a Gaza hospital tent camp, killing 2 Palestinians and hurting journalists
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An Israeli airstrike hit a tent camp in the courtyard of a crowded hospital in central Gaza on Sunday, killing two Palestinians and wounding another 15, including journalists working nearby.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians carry a wounded person following an Israeli airstrike
media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry a wounded person following an Israeli airstrike near the Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: GOP Rep. Tim Walberg suggests Gaza should be handled 'like Nagasaki and Hiroshima'
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Cohen and Emma Li
item.description: Rep. Tim Walberg, R-Mich., said this week that the conflict in Gaza should be over quickly "like Nagasaki and Hiroshima."

media:content.media:text: Fast food workers and their supporters march past the state Capitol calling on passage of a bill to provide increased power to fast-food workers in Sacramento, Calif., on Aug. 16, 2022.
